Detailed Description

Contain a set of tabs as well as the ability to render them.

There are three 'areas' of a tabset.

  • title: The clickable link to display the tab area. These are always visible.
  • body: The actual HTML body of the tab. Only one body is visible at a time.
  • extra: An optional decorative area around the tabs.

Member Function Documentation

views_tabset::add ( $  name,
$  title = '',
$  body = '' 
)

Add a tab to the tabset.

Parameters:
$name The name of the tab; this is the internal identifier and must be unique within the tabset.
$title If given, this will be the visible title of the tab. This can also be set via $tabset->set(). This will be the link to click on to view the tab.
$body If given, this is the body of the tab itself. It will display when the tab title is clicked on.

views_tabset::add_extra ( $  text  ) 

Add text to the 'extra' region of the tabset.

views_tabset::add_tab ( $  tab  ) 

Add a fully realized tab object to the tabset.

Parameters:
$tab A fully populated views_tab object.

views_tabset::remove ( $  tab  ) 

Remove a tab.

Parameters:
$tab May be the name of the tab or a views_tab object.

views_tabset::render (  ) 

Output the HTML for the tabs.

Returns:
HTML representation of the tabs.

$  title,
$  body = NULL 
)

Set the values of a tab.

Parameters:
$name The unique identifier of the tab to set.
$title The title of the tab; this will be clickable.
$body The HTML body of the tab.
